question: Satire. 1a. A literary work in which human vice or folly is ridiculed or attacked scornfully. B. The branch of literature that composes such work. 2. Irony, derision or caustic wit used to attack or expose folly, vice or stupidity. Bonjour, my name is Pierre Delacroix. I'm a television writer, also a showrunner, a creative person. I'm one of those people responsible for what you view on your idiot box.
answer: Monogrammed cuff sleeve - the initials P.D.

question: The problem is not enough of you have been watching.
answer: Monogrammed shirt pocket - the initials P.D.

question: With the onslaught of the internet, video and interactive games, nine hundred channels to choose from and whatnot, our valued audience has dramatically eroded.
answer: Razor cuts a path through a white foam on a black face.

question: To put it in much more simple terms... Like rats fleeing a sinking ship.
answer: The handsome face of Pierre Delacroix.

question: Thank you very much but please don't go without giving us some cheddar, cheese, money. We prefer two's than fews. I would like to add that both of us are homeless. Not that it means anything. I said homeless. Ladies and gentlemen. Senorita, do you know what that means? Muchos gracias.
answer: Good morning, Cheeba.

question: Good morning to you, Mr. Delapot.
answer: De-la-croix.

question: Y'know what I mean. Got a gig yet for Manray and I yet?
answer: Not yet.

question: Gracias.
answer: Manray, Sloan says you're too talented to be dancing on the street.

question: Good morning, Marie. What staff meeting?
answer: Monsieur Delacroix, this very important meeting commenced... ...exactly thirty-two minutes ago. I'm sorry I'm late. Do you know how much information can be dispensed in one minute alone?

question: I didn't find out about this very important staff meeting until... Four minutes ago.
answer: So are you telling me everyone knew about this get-together except you?

question: I wasn't told about this until Marie informed me as soon as I got off the elevator.
answer: People, you can attempt to pull a Rodman like our friend Delacroix, but I guarantee you'll be sent packing just like him. These are the standings. Read 'em and weep. As you can plainly see the Continental Network System is languishing.

question: People, you can attempt to pull a Rodman like our friend Delacroix, but I guarantee you'll be sent packing just like him. These are the standings. Read 'em and weep. As you can plainly see the Continental Network System is languishing.
answer: Ratings charts.

question: Look at 'em people. We are BOOTY, CA CA. We are DOO-DOO. Doo-doo on a stick, if you will.
answer: Dunwitty.

question: I do not like to be the laughing stock of the broadcast industry. I have pride and people, you better start getting some too. These numbers have to go up. Question? What I want everyone to do is write some material that is FUNNY. The junk you've been writing is about as funny as a dead baby. It's not funny, it's not new. It's not sexy. It, it, it...
answer: Fish.

question: How was it?
answer: Why didn't you tell me about this staff meeting?

question: Nobody told me anything.
answer: What good are you if you don't tell me stuff like this?

question: Do you know what C.P. Time is?
answer: C.P. Time is Colored People's Time. The stereotypical belief that Negroes are always late. That Negroes have no sense of time - time except when it comes to music or dance.

question: Let's sit down over there. I'm sorry about my blowup but I have to have a whipping boy every meeting.
answer: I understand. But again, in all honesty I was not informed.

question: Forget it. I believe you're my most creative person I've got on staff. You're hip. You know what's happening. I got some corny white boys and girls writing for me. I understand Black culture. I grew up around black people all my life. If the truth be told I probably know "niggers" better than you, Monsieur Delacroix. Please don't get offended by my use of the quote-unquote N word. I got a black wife and three bi-racial children, so I feel I have a right to use that word. I don't give a damn what Spike says, Tarantino is right. Nigger is just a word. If Dirty Ole Bastard can use it every other word so can I.
answer: I would prefer you not use that word in my presence. Say it again. C'mon, say it again.

question: Who's a nigger now?
answer: The material you've been creating is too white bread. White people with black faces. The Huxtable's, Cosby, revolutionary. But that's dead. We can't go down that road again.

question: I don't agree. The Negro middle class does exist, and it's rich material for a dramatic series or sitcom.
answer: I'm telling you it's not. The middle class black family moves into a white suburban enclave. The middle class black family moves into a small Southern town that is run by the KKK. The middle class single black father raises his teenage daughter. The middle class single black father raises his teenage daughter. The middle class single black mother raises her teenage son. And so on and so forth. It's too clean, too antiseptic...

question: ...to white? I still feel all of my scripts would make good shows.
answer: Delacroix, wake up, brother man. The reason why they didn't get picked up was because nobody - and I mean NOBODY - niggers and crackers alike wants to see that junk.

question: I've never been given a fair shot.
answer: You got your head stuck up your ass with your Harvard education and your pretentious ways. Brother man, I'm blacker than you. I'm keepin' it real and you're frontin', trying to be white.

question: I'm an oreo, a sell out? Because I don't aspire to do HOMEBOYS FROM OUT OF SPACE, SECRET DIARY OF DESMOND PFEIFFER, A PJ's or some as you might put it, some "nigger" show? I'm a Tom? I'm whiter than white and you're blacker than black? Is that what you think?
answer: That's exactly what I think. I want you to create something that people want to see. Let's be honest, the majority of the people in the country are deaf, dumb and blind and I'm including 35 million African-Americans. You know and I know "niggers" set the trend, set the styles. This is a golden opportunity now. These idiots have to be led to the water.

question: I'm not sure if I can deliver what you want.
answer: You will or you'll be back at BET so quick you'll never know what hit you. I need a mid-season replacement and pronto. It will be on the fast track.

question: What is it you want from me? Some plantation follies? Some sitcom that takes place on a watermelon patch? Some show that follows four nigger generations of junkies and crackheads? You want me to go back to the ante bellum days?
answer: Yes! Yes! Yes! I want a show that will make headlines, that will have millions and millions of households tuned in, glued to their televisions every week. I want advertisers dying to buy on this show. I'm gonna squeeze this show out of you if it kills you.

question: I'm starvin' like Marvin.
answer: My world famous, famous world Arroz con pollo will be ready very soon.

question: Hurry up, I wanna watch HBO.
answer: Did we get our bill yet?

question: I guess that will come with the rent, gas, and Con Ed bills, too.
answer: Ahh, the luxuries of life.

question: Yo, check it. This is good and all that but one day soon I want to have much Benjamins so I can have a nice crib and pay all my bills. You hear me.
answer: Chill, I'm the brains behind this outfit.

question: And I'm the feet.
answer: Yo, you gotta show some patience. You want me to snap my fingers and presto chango - you're an overnight sensation. Son, there is no such thing.

question: Delacroix, staring at the blank ream of paper. It is very intimidating. Monitor. Bernie Williams is at the plate for the New York Yankees. Sign atop monitor. Again, it reads "FEED THE IDIOT BOX."
answer: Delacroix grabs a pencil and put it to paper.

question: Paper. He doodles.
answer: Delacroix is already in the bed, the lights are out.

question: Manray!
answer: Manray!

question: How did you know?
answer: It hit me like a ton of bricks.

question: How can this be? You and me at the same time, the exact same thought. It's scary.
answer: The idea was out there in the universe. Now what?

question: Manray was under our nose the whole time.
answer: Do you know how you will use him?

question: Not yet, but this thing will never get made.
answer: You lost me.

question: Dunwitty wants a Coon show. And that's what I'm going to give him, it's going to be so racist, so negative, he won't have the balls to put it on the air. Hence I'll prove my point.
answer: What point is that?

question: The point being that him, the networks don't want Black people on television unless they are buffoons.
answer: Sounds risky to me.

question: You getting cold feet?
answer: I'm in till the end.

question: Good. I'm going to need your support.
answer: Can't you just quit? Walk away?

question: And lose out on my money? The only way I get paid is if I get fired. And that's what I intend to do. Everything was going according to plan. I was working on the outline. Dunwitty was off my back for now.
answer: Delacroix.

question: But there was a catch. A big catch.
answer: Sloan.

question: It was like they had disappeared off the face of the earth.
answer: Cheeba.

question: I had no contact numbers, no address, no beeper.
answer: Manray.

question: Manray needs a job.
answer: We got evicted from our home. We've both been on the streets for the last week.

question: We was coming to see you.
answer: If it's not too much trouble could you order us some food?

question: Different.
answer: How different?

question: Trust me. Of course I still have to pitch it to my boss, but we'll have an answer one way or the other.
answer: DeLa, I'm aboard. As long as I get to hoof and get paid too!!!

question: You'll both get an advance and you can stay with me.
answer: Bet.

question: I would like to change your name.
answer: To what?

question: You're now Mantan.
answer: Mantan? I don't even care as long as I'm dancing. Which reminds me, I need some new kicks. I never had a really real pair before.

question: Mantan? I don't even care as long as I'm dancing. Which reminds me, I need some new kicks. I never had a really real pair before.
answer: You've never had any formal training, either?

question: Not a class, not a thing, just picked stuff up by myself.
answer: I wish I had your natural talent. God only makes that visit once in a while.

question: You sing and dance?
answer: A little. I just graduated from NYU film school. Cinema studies.

question: So what's up with you and DeLa?
answer: What do you mean?

question: Are you and him kicking it? Knocking boots. Y'knowwhatI'mtalkin'bout.
answer: No, we're not knocking boots. I got this internship while I still was at NYU, DeLa was impressed with my get up and go and hired me to be his assistant.

question: I'm sure that was the only thing he was impressed with. You look beautiful like that.
answer: If that was suppose to be a compliment, I thank you.

question: You're welcome. You shouldn't give up on performing.
answer: Why do you say that? You've never seen me.

question: I think that would probably make you the happiest. When I'm hoofing, I mean really doing my thing, hitting it, nothing compares to that feeling in the world.
answer: I envy you. That's the way I want to feel about my work.

question: You idiot. You almost gave me a massive coronary.
answer: I didn't mean to scare you like that.

question: Well you did.
answer: Give me some?

question: I'm not huggin' you in the middle of the street. You must be crazy, Julius.
answer: Whoa, hold up li'l sis'. I done told you 'bout that. Julius ain't my name, you better recognize Hopkins was our slave name. My true name is...

question: I'm not callin you Big Black Africa. Mommy and Daddy named you Julius.
answer: BIG BLACK is the first name and AFRICA is the last. Damn, Sis, you don't keep no food up in here in dis' piece.

question: I order out mostly. So what do I owe this visit to?
answer: My group we need some exposure. Was wondering if you could hook a brother up?

question: Hook you up? The Mau-Mau's? You must be smoking. Why in the world would I want to hook up a bunch of red, black and green flag-waving pseudo revolutionairies?
answer: So now I see where you're coming from. Just because we ain't rapping about Gucci, Timberland, Rolex, Benz, Cristal, ho's and bitches, we're pseudo.

question: Who are you revolting against?
answer: We're revolting against the powers that be, that been enslaving the minds and hearts of all people of color. And we won't stop rapping till we bring about the overthrow of the government of the U.S. of A.

question: Please.
answer: If you were really down you would get us together with that boss of yours. What's his name again?

question: Delacroix.
answer: Yeah, him.

question: What makes you think he would write a show about the Mau-Mau's.
answer: C'mon, why not? The Monkees had a show. Look at all that other junk that's on TV. We got underground cult following.

question: You don't have the demographics.
answer: So are you telling me that you wouldn't even introduce me to Delacroix or set up a meeting? I'm talking 'bout me, your only brother, ya own flesh and blood, hook a brother up, youknowwhatI'msayin'.

question: That'swhatI'msayin'. I'm not blowin' my young career, brother or no brother, for you or anybody else.
answer: There is a name, a term for your kind, the likes of you. Back in slavery days, you would be classified as a house nigga.

question: If you think I'm a house nigga then that's your prerogative. You got your ways to affect change, I have mine. And I would appreciate it very much if you took ya field nigga ass out of my house.
answer: My own sister throwin' me out. I hope to seeya later when you get ya mind right. Don't bother letting me out.

question: Good. I like the names. Very theatrical.
answer: We're all happy to be here and I'm going to paint a picture for you.

question: I'm wid it.
answer: I've done a lot of soul searching and once again you are right. In my previous work it's been all surface, superficial. I have never really dug deep. Not anymore. As Mark Twain fully understood satire is the way. Race has always been a hot button in this country's history and it needs to be pushed harder. If we are ever to live side by side in peace and harmony. It's about promoting racial healing.

question: Go on. Good so far.
answer: I know you're familiar with minstrel shows. They came about at the turn of the 19th century. It was a variety show in which the talent was in blackface - singing, dancing, telling jokes, doing skits. Dunwitty, I ask you when was the last time there was a good variety show on the air. Carol Burnett? HeeHaw?

question: Word!!!
answer: So let's take this great form, this very American tradition of entertainment into the 21st century, into the new millennium.

question: The name of the show?
answer: It is called

question: I'm lovin' it. You know how I know? Because I'm getting a boner, my Johnson is hard, no disrespect my sister. I'm feelin' dis'!
answer: It will take a lot of courage and backbone on the part of the CNS to get this on the air. In fact, I would understand fully if the subject matter is deemed too risque, too controversial.

question: Don't worry about that, that's my department. Now who do we cast? We need a star. Can Whoopi sing or dance?
answer: I don't know if Whoopi is the way to go.

question: That's a great handle.
answer: Mantan and Sleep 'n Eat. Two real coons. I know we're way out there but it's satire.

question: I want you take it there. All the way to the edge and back.
answer: Every week we follow the trials and tribulations of two real coons - Mantan and Sleep 'n Eat. The Dusky Duo.

question: What are there character traits?
answer: Ignorant, dullwitted, lazy, and unlucky.

question: Exactly!
answer: Mantan is an uneducated Negro who always by some stroke of unbelievable stupidity makes his best laid plans go haywire.

question: And Sleep 'n Eat is his comical sidekick?
answer: Yep, you guessed it.

question: This could be bigger than "Amos and Andy."
answer: Protest finally forced "Amos and Andy" off the air. Could stop us from ever getting on.

question: Let'em try. I will kill to make this happen.
answer: Negroes would be in an uproar.

question: So what. We would just give the NAACP a donation that would be the end of that. No such thing as bad publicity. So what. Earlier you said singing and dancing.
answer: Mantan right here is a gifted hoofer. He has educated feet.

question: Who are the other characters?
answer: Do we have characters? How about Honeycutt, Snowflake, Rastus, Nigger, Jim, Sambo, Jungle Bunny, and how could we forget Aunt Jemima.

question: We gonna hit 'em wid da BOMB DICKEY on dis' one. What's the setting?
answer: In the projects. Like Eddie Murphy's "The PJ's."

question: Ya first bad move. Projects been done. That's one of the problems now, everything, movies, TV, are set in the urban jungle, da hood. That's so tired. Mantan's Millennium Minstrel Show should be set on a plantation. In Alabama. And every week these Alabama porch monkeys will make us cry, make us laugh, make us look at our own humanity. Make us feel good to be alive.
answer: I don't know about that plantation angle.

question: Sleep 'n Eat, what do you do?
answer: I play the straight man. I do some singing and dancing also. I also manage Mantan.

question: Oh you do so?
answer: I'm the man behind the man behind the man.

question: You da man.
answer: No, you da man.

question: I'm gonna run upstairs with this. If CNS doesn't want to do this, somebody else will have da balls to pull the trigger. I want to thank each and every one of you. This is great, Delacroix. I'll get back to you later today.
answer: Life is beginning to look up. It's all good in da neighborhood.

question: Life is beginning to look up. It's all good in da neighborhood.
answer: You might be right.

question: Why are you smiling so?
answer: I'm not smiling.

question: Naw, not you. It can't be. That hottie Sloan Hopkins.
answer: It's that bad, huh? It's all over my face.

question: No shame in ya game. She got ya nostrils, ya chnoz is wide open. Sloan's what we certified ladies' men call low hanging fruit.
answer: Certified ladies' man, huh?

question: She's also moorish.
answer: What's that?

question: Moorish. Ya get a little taste of dat booty, ya wanna get some MORE.
answer: Seconds and thirds, too.

question: Sloan is all 'dat. I try her. I'm a tri-sexual.
answer: You'd try anything. I got first dibs. You get ya own stuff.

question: You must think I'm some kind of fool.
answer: It looks delicious.

question: You hear me talkin' to you. The only time you come up here when something is wrong.
answer: C'mon, Mommy, don't start with that I'm an ungrateful son stuff.

question: I said no such thing. All I said is that something must be wrong. How's the food?
answer: Can't beat it with a hammer. Well, since you asked, it looks like I may have a new show, a pilot being shot.

question: That's wonderful. Isn't that what you always wanted, a show of your own?
answer: It was. It is. But this is a different kind of show.

question: If at first it's not what you want, just work that much harder, Peerless.
answer: Mommy, please don't call me that.

question: Son, Peerless is your name. Now you might be one of these Hollywood types, change your name and all that but Peerless Dothan is on your birth certificate.
answer: I know what's on my birth certificate. You heard from Daddy?

question: I guess he's still on the road. What kind of show is this? Are they some Negroes in it without being buffoons?
answer: To answer your question, there are a lot of Negroes in it and what is your definition of buffoons?

question: Peerless, I didn't raise a buffoon. We have enough of those on television already.
answer: Please let me know when you hear from Daddy, get a number or something.

question: Well, homeboy, looks like he's at a funeral.
answer: I'm happy for all of us. It's just we have a great responsibility now. The pressure is on.

question: Pressure? DeLa, you don't know what the hell real pressure is. SHEEETT!!! This is lightstuff. Now when you scramblin' out on the street in da January winter and the hawk is talkin' to you with NO money and NO prospects of money anytime soon, now that there is some pressure.
answer: I didn't mean it to sound like that.

question: That's the way it came out. Let me ask you one question. Have you ever been in want, in need your entire privileged life?
answer: Now I'm privileged?! Why? Because I didn't grow up on food stamps and welfare? Because I didn't call home a cardboard box? No, I never ever went to bed hungry and I'm proud of it, too. Whoever told you that living in poverty earns you somekind of badge of honor flat out lied to you.

question: I'm Cheeba.
answer: I'm Mantan.

question: Please, have a seat.
answer: Sloan never told us she had friends like you.

question: What is your problem?
answer: My problem is MANTAN THE NEW

question: Why did you even come up with that shit if you didn't want it made?
answer: It was the principle. Dunwitty had to be enlightened. I was making a point. I take pride in my work. Plus, I already told you I wasn't gonna walk away from my money.

question: Fuck da money. Why do through all this effort? Why? Are you looking for love from Dunwitty? For respect? Dunwitty and his likes don't give a goddamn about you. So now what are you gonna do? You're gonna have to hold it in because we're not finished yet... ...QUIT then.
answer: Even if money wasn't an issue, Dunwitty will still go ahead without me and that could be more dangerous.

question: What's the chances of MANTAN being picked up?
answer: I wouldn't bet against it. My Negroidal ass is stuck between the proverbial rock and a hard place.

question: I strongly feel that a Negro should direct this. This kind of satire is a high wire act in a gale storm. One misstep and we're doing "Amos and Andy." Only a Negro will have the sensitivity and cultural awareness to navigate this dangerous terrain.
answer: To hire someone solely on their ethnicity, gender or religion is not right. It's un-American. I will hire someone who is most qualified for this particular job.

question: I was hoping to perhaps direct some episodes myself, if not the pilot soon after.
answer: I want a hot, young white director. Maybe the kid, that pheenom who just did that hot new sexy Madonna video.

question: You're telling me some white boy is gonna direct this pilot?
answer: I just want you to meet him. Keep an open mind.

question: Besides, what does he know about Negroes?
answer: Probably nuthin', but that's why it's such a sexy way to go. Sometimes an outsider has a fresh new outlook, a different unique perspective. A black director, y'know what he's gonna do given the subject matter? With this kid, the possibilities are endless.

question: What are his qualifications besides being a white male and directing a hot new sexy freaky Madonna video?
answer: If Spielburg can direct "The Color Purple" and "Amistad", our whiz kid can direct the Mantan pilot.

question: That's exactly my point. Has he even directed actors before in anything?
answer: No!!! Just meet the guy. That's all I'm asking. Look, I'll even let you choose your own musical director. You can have that.

question: In the immortal words of Derrick Coleman, WHOOOPDEEDAMNDOO!!!
answer: Derrick Coleman, he possessed all the talent in the world, coulda, shoulda, been a great ballplayer but alas D.C. didn't want it bad enough. Delacroix, do you want it? Bad enough to kill for it? Do you want it that much.

question: This was amazing. Who had told these Negroes that this was what we were looking for? The same old image, it damn for sure wasn't me.
answer: Lulu.

question: Were people this desperate to get work?
answer: Delacroix. He interrupts Lulu.

question: The Mau-Mau's are up in dis place. That's right, the Mau-Mau's.
answer: What's your name?

question: My righteous name is BIG BLACK.
answer: And what are the Mau-Mau's going to do for us today?

question: Dunwitty, don't leave. Where are you from?
answer: Helsinki, which is the capital of Finland.

question: Finland.
answer: You know, Finlandia vodka? Yes?

question: Yes, I know. Jukka, have you ever seen a Negro person before? Even had a real conversation with a real Negro before?
answer: What's a Negro.

question: A fiasco. A disaster. A boondoggle. An abomination. Did you just ask me what's a Negro? I'M A NEGRO!!!
answer: Ahhh!!! I never heard of that term before. I thought you were BLACK of African-American. No?

question: Well before there was BLACK or AFRICAN AMERICAN, there were
answer: Thank you for correcting my ignorance. I'm looking forward to working side by side with you. I feel we make a good team.

question: How did you get this gig?
answer: My visual style is very erotic, sexy, how do you say - hot?

question: This is a TV show, not a music video.
answer: Then will you teach me what I need to know. Maybe we learn from each other, if that's possible, no?

question: Wait a minute. Hold up. Can I kiss you too?
answer: Naw. I'll take the zero.

question: You feel good, not nervous?
answer: I feel fine.

question: Not nervous? Relaxed?
answer: Sloan, will you take your boss out of here so I can get ready.

question: Good. I'm not sure about this material.
answer: The material is fine.

question: You really think so?
answer: We're trying to do something new here, some groundbreaking stuff.

question: Same here.
answer: The pleasure is mine.

question: I guess it was divine inspiration.
answer: Divine inspiration?

question: I was trying to be nice.
answer: I want to apologize about my brother and the Mau-Mau's. I should not have imposed them on you.

question: This is my best friend Sleep 'N Eat.
answer: And this is my very best friend Mantan.

question: We both left the hustle and bustle of Uptown, Harlem...
answer: ...the big apple, New York, New York.

question: To come back to our roots.
answer: Our Alabamy Home. Now we're getting countrified. We is Bama's.

question: No mo' "city slickers." Ahh, can't you smell the sweet aroma of the ripe watermelons and high cotton?
answer: Tell 'em what you mean Mistuh Mantan.

question: Well, thank you Mistuh Sleep 'N Eat.
answer: Give or cousins some of dem educated feets. Cousins, first, second, third and distant, let's have Mantan take us all the way back to a much more simpler time. A time wen men were men, women were women, and Neggras knew their place.

question: Cousins, I want all of you to go to your windows. Go to your windows and yell. Yell, I'm tired of the drugs, the crack babies born out of wedlock to crackhead aids infested parents. I'm tired of the inflated welfare rolls while good wholesome Americans bring less and less of their paycheck home every two weeks. I'm tired, you're tired, we're all tired of these so-called bible- thumping God fearing, whore mongling Professional athletes. Aren't you tired of these basketball-dunking, football-running, hop-hip rapping ebonic-speaking sex offenders who got ten kids from ten different Ho's? I know I am and so is Sleep 'N Eat.
answer: You tellin' the truth.

question: Hello?
answer: Yo, DeLa, I just got the news from the CNS brass. They saw some clips from the pilot and they're rushing it onto the air. Yo, we're a midseason replacement, ordered 12 shows. We're on in 3 weeks. Didya hear what I just said, Yo? They didn't even view a rough cut, just some scenes we quickly cut together.

question: This has to be a big mistake.
answer: The big mistake was my not believing in your genius earlier. From the gitgo, from jump street.

question: Hold on a sec, I got a call. Hello, Mommy, let me get rid of this other call. I gots to go, it's my Moms.
answer: I want to meet her one day, please tell her the great news. I'm OUT like Vanilla Ice.

question: So what's up with you?
answer: What do you want to know?

question: The good stuff.
answer: I'm an asthmatic. Been one all my life. Can't go anywhere without an inhaler.

question: What else?
answer: Are you trying to rap to me?

question: He wants you to come and see him.
answer: He said that?

question: Yes he did.
answer: Where is he?

question: He's performing at some place outside of Richmond, Virginia.
answer: I can't go all the way down south.

question: Richmond is not all the way down south.
answer: I don't even know why you're still concerned over him. Daddy's not with you.

question: Regardless, he still is your father.
answer: It's gonna be hard for me to get away with the show taking off.

question: Even more reason to see him. He'll be overjoyed with your success.
answer: C'mon, Mommy. Daddy hasn't been impressed with anything I've ever done. From winning my fifth grade Spelling Bee to the present.

question: 'Cuse me. Please. Can you please show me some respect. I'm up here trying to make a living. Don't make me have to come over there and whoop you upside ya head. Just messin' with ya. But please if you and your lady need to discuss something, take it outside. Thank you.
answer: Brother man, that's my father up there and I drove a long way to see him perform. Please take this fifty, go buy you and the young lady some drinks in the club.

question: Don't bring your woman out if you can't keep her in deep check. If my woman ever did something crazy like that I'd put my size 12 dead up in her ass. What do you want?
answer: I want to speak with you.

question: Go away, unless you got my money.
answer: It's me, Peerless.

question: Son. Good to seeya. Good to seeya.
answer: It's been a long time.

question: Pull up a chair. Oh, excuse me, this is my lady DOT.
answer: Pleased to meet you.

question: Good woman. I trained her right.
answer: Daddy, she's younger than me.

question: My game is still strong. No Viagra for me, don't need no chemicals. Just my tonic. Purely for medicinal purposes.
answer: I thought you had promised Mommy you stopped.

question: I did. I'm not an alcoholic. I just like to drink.
answer: How did you end up here?

question: How did I end up at the third rate chittlin' circuit greasy hole in the wall in West Hell, Virginny? Is that what you're asking ya Daddy?
answer: That's what I'm askin'.

question: Because I had too much pride. Too much integrity. I wouldn't lick nobody's butt. Some material I refused to do.
answer: Daddy, it can't be just because of that. There had to be other factors.

question: That's the only reason, period. They only want one certain kind of black comic.
answer: Another one of your conspiracies to hold ya career back?

question: All I know is what happened to me. All that other mess I just file into the "life's too short" category. Enough about me, what's happening with you?
answer: The same old, same old. Trying to get my stuff through.

question: Dem white boys giving you a hard time?
answer: Nuthin' I can't handle.

question: The truth is never let them seeya sweat. You do that, that's half the battle.
answer: Where do you go from here?

question: Three nights Charleston, South Carolina.
answer: I didn't mean that, in life.

question: Let's get him over to the bed.
answer: Baby, you treat me so good. Peerless, you're a good son, I love you. You never gave me no trouble.

question: I love you too, Daddy.
answer: Always keep 'em laughing.

question: How long has my father been like this?
answer: Not that often. He was excited to see you.

question: So he drank himself into a stuper?
answer: The drinking is for the pain. It doesn't kill it, just dulls it.

question: So what's up with you?
answer: I was a hostess at this club, your Daddy was performing and I had never laughed so hard in my life. He asked me to come with him. I quit my job and we've been together ever since.

question: Don't tell him it's from me or he won't take it.
answer: Your father is proud of you.

question: He never showed it.
answer: He did the best way he knew how, Junebug is stubborn just like you. I'll take care of him.

question: Everybody say Ho!
answer: Ho!

question: That'swhatI'mtalkin'bout! That'swhatI'mtalkin'bout! I want to be the first to welcome you to the second taping of Mantan - The New Millennium Minstrel Show. My name is Honeycutt and I want to try something different. Can you do this for me?
answer: Yeah!

question: I'm gonna start a chant and I want y'all to follow me. Let's make our own 2 real coons know you're ready to start the show. Let's go Niggers. Then clap five times like this. C'mon. It's easy. It's the same thing y'all do out at the Yankee game, no different 'cept we changing one word. Everybody go it?
answer: YEAH!

question: Alright. Here we go. Let's go NIGGERS! LET'S GO NIGGERS!
answer: Let's go NIGGERS.

question: Y'know my lady Lucindy?
answer: The one with da big...

question: Not her, the one with the little...
answer: Oh her.

question: Tomorrow is her birthday and I want to get her something really nice, like a...
answer: No, not that. How 'bout...

question: She hates dem.
answer: Too bad. How 'bout a dress?

question: Sleep 'N Eat, one of dem slinky, sexy, little foxy...
answer: Mantan, way too short, too tight. Get her one of dose...

question: ...to big. The in-between one, not too tight, not too lose.
answer: That'll work. I just bought one for myself. Not for me, my woolly headed cotton pickin' friend for...

question: I thought you got rid of...
answer: ...that was Vicki, her best friend. Dat dress will cast ya round...

question: ...dat's too much money. I can't 'ford it. I needs me a dress that cost no mo' than...
answer: ...aconite get it dat cheap.

question: I'll buy her a less expensive dress, so I can have some money left over to take her out to dinner.
answer: We should go out on a double date.

question: I heard ya lady is wild.
answer: No. That's her second cousin. Who's married to Li'l Bit.

question: Oh, because on our first date, she let me...
answer: ...no, she didn't...

question: ...yes she did.
answer: ...I heard different, thought that was...

question: ...not that time...
answer: So when are you comin' to pick us up?

question: Around...
answer: ...too early...

question: ...then what about...
answer: ...too late, maybe around...

question: ...perfect...
answer: That's what I like about you and me. We git along...

question: ...like macaroni and cheese...
answer: ...like grits and butter...

question: ...like fried and chicken...
answer: ...like sleep and eat. We'd better hide.

question: I'm not black. I'm a NEGRO!!!
answer: So you have your small victory, now what?

question: A small victory isn't that small when you've been use to losing. What is this?
answer: A gift.

question: For what?
answer: No matter what you think, you did come up with something unique. Open it. Put a coin in the hand. Watch this. Read it on the back.

question: The Jolly Nigger Bank.
answer: This is authentic, not a repro, circa turn of the century.

question: Thanks.
answer: I thought it was appropiate.

question: Is that good or bad?
answer: It's all good. You got a hit show, you're gonna need a bank. Plus, I love these old black collectibles.

question: How so?
answer: To me, it shows part of our history in this country, a time when we were considered inferior, sub-human.

question: Why is Jess and Reverend Al down there?
answer: So they can be on TV.

question: You sound like the media.
answer: This is nothing. It will blow over by tomorrow.

question: Same thing Giuliani said.
answer: Tomorrow it will be all about cruelty to animals or some sex scandal. Besides, there is no such thing as bad publicity. Rest your mind. It's a little somethin' something. Those were the last pair of tap shoes worn by Bill "Bojangles" Robinson. In fact, he died with them on. No joke. Serious.

question: Hope the same thing doesn't happen to me. That's some big shoes to fill.
answer: In time.

question: This is a nice place. It must have cost a pretty penny.
answer: Sloan, I got it like 'dat.

question: Oh you do, huh?
answer: Just a little something' somethin'.

question: I hope you save a little somethin' somethin'.
answer: Gots no intention of ending up broke.

question: Y'know, at the beginnin' of the century, African-American had to perform in blackface. You ever heard of Bert Williams? He was a great artist.
answer: No, before my time.

question: You don't read, do you?
answer: Never read a book in my whole life.

question: Maybe you need to start.
answer: Maybe I need to do a lot of things.

question: Bert Williams and the rest, they had to black up. They had no choice. They were considered 3/5ths of a human being. Did you know that's written in the Constitution of the United States?
answer: Why all of a sudden are you flippin' on me? This blackface thing was part of the deal from the git-go. Don't even try to play it like you ain't a part of all this. You down with Delacroix.

question: I just don't want you and Cheeba to get hurt.
answer: We can look out for ourselves.

question: I fell out of my bed last night.
answer: You slept too near where you got in?

question: I slept too near where I fell out.
answer: You expect the unexpected in circumstances of that peculiarity.

question: Sleep 'N Eat, what's the matter with you? Using all dose ten dollar words?
answer: Mantan, it is possible that my hyphenated sentences are entirely too complex for all the intellect contained in that diminutive coconut?

question: Hold on, you allegorical hypothesis. Don't cross words with me.
answer: Ain't Jemima on the pancake box?

question: Dat's yo Uncle Ben. That reminds me, I've seen a lot of troubles lately.
answer: How be dat?

question: I don't know who I am.
answer: Well, I'll be an Alabama porch monkey's uncle.

question: Years ago I married a widow who had a grown-up daughter. My daddy visited us often, fell in love with my stepdaughter and married her. Thusly he became my son-in-law and my stepdaughter became my mother because she was my father's wife. Soon after dis my wife gave birth to a son, which of course was my father's brother in-law and my uncle, for he was the brother of my step-mother. My father's wife also became the mother of a son. He was of course my brother and also my grandchild for he was the son of my daughter. Accordingly, my wife was my grandmother because she was my mother's mother. Sleep 'N Eat, I was my wife's husband and grandchild at one and the same time. And lo' and behold, as the husband of a person's grandmother is his grandfather, I Mantan, became my own grandfather.
answer: Mantan, dat sho' is a whopper.

question: I'm tired of you pickaninnies messing up my choreography. It goes like this. Try it again. Better. Let's take a ten minute break.
answer: I'm not drinking the Kool-Aid.

question: What are you talkin' about?
answer: Jim Jones, y'know. I'm not drinking the Kool-Aid.

question: Meaning?
answer: I'm out.

question: Good. I've got a broken back from carrying you all these years anyway.
answer: So that's what you been doing?

question: Damn skippy.
answer: You're in this up till ya neck.

question: Don't shoot me, I'm just the piano players.
answer: You can walk away. We both can.

question: Yeah, that's easy for you to do. You never had any talent.
answer: I'm so tired of you running that. I always worked hard for you. You think I'm a leech, a kling-on, I quit.

question: I'm the star of Mantan, so you do that. Quit, walk away. And don't come crawling back, either.
answer: Why don't you call him?

question: For what? He left. Not me.
answer: You're sure this is a good idea.

question: My people love me.
answer: I love you. I'll be down front. You better start putting your face on.

question: Y'know what?
answer: What?

question: Pull ya self together. What are you? A man or a mouse? Are you a punk? Punking out on me?
answer: No.

question: You getting scared because some people don't like what you are doing?
answer: Yo, DeLa, they tried to lynch my black ass up in dat piece.

question: You've made it from the guttermost to the uppermost. Don't you know you should never let them see you sweat. Y'knowwhatI'msayin'?
answer: Yeah.

question: Our guest tonight is the extraordinary, talented performer, Mantan. Thanks for coming in.
answer: Tavis, thank you for having me.

question: Before we begin, I want to thank you for coming on my show for your first television interview. You could have chosen Mike Wallace, Barbara Walters, Jane Pauley, whatnot but you're here.
answer: I'm more comfortable around my people.

question: Let's jump right into it. Your show has sparked a world of controversy, provoked a tone of dialogue. How do you see all of this?
answer: Yo, Tavis, check it out. This is the two-one, the 21st century and it's all about the money. Like my man Mase says, "it's all about the Benjamins."

question: Money and nothing else?
answer: Money makes the world go round. It ain't no joke being poor. I know whatI'mtalkin''bout. Y'knowwhatI'msayin'? I've lived on the street. I've been homeless. I've learned how to play the game, work the game, be in the game.

question: Is it inevitable that the game plays you?
answer: No if you go with the flow, Tavis. That's what a lot of Negroes don't understand. Protesting isn't gonna do a damn thing. If people don't like our satire in our number one hit show then don't watch it. Or better yet write your own show. Do it better.

question: Don't you feel that is a simplistic retort?
answer: I don't know what a retort is, but it's simple. Mantan - The New Millennium Minstrel Show is UNIVERSAL. It's not just for Negroes in Compton or 125th in Harlem. This is America. Our ancestors helped build this country, we got a right, just like everybody else. I'm not gonna box myself in. This show makes people think, and they're laughing at the same time.

question: Microphone check, one, two. One, two. Yo Tavis, I be lovin' yo show but Mantan you is foul. Why you perpetrating? You a sellout.
answer: That's our opinion.

question: You're a traitor to the race. A tool for the Caucasoids.
answer: Why? Because I'm successful? Because I don't use "Causcasoids" as an excuse for not fulfilling my dreams?

question: I ain't hearing all dat noise. You getting played and you don't even know it.
answer: And Big Black from Brooklyn, what do you do?

question: What do I do?
answer: What do you do?

question: Why'd you do that?
answer: I don't want to hear it.

question: How long have you and Hambone been hangin' out?
answer: You're the one that put us together. We're friends.

question: That crazy brother of yours doesn't think so.
answer: He's just playing big brother.

question: Oh, is he? You getting jiggy with Mantan?
answer: Please don't go there.

question: Dunwitty and I feel you've been getting too close to him, getting his mind all messed up.
answer: I can't lie to him. If he asks me something, I tell him what I think.

question: Do you have to be so damn forthright?
answer: DeLa, you should try it sometime. Come into the light.

question: Light?
answer: That which has been hidden in darkness is now in the light. This bucket of blood.

question: You can talk all that mumbo jumbo if you want to but your hands are much bloody. I know where I made my big mistake. I have a general rule, never get involved romantically with somebody crazier than you. This is crazy.
answer: That's why it will be so much fun. That was a mistake, but I don't regret it.

question: The first and only time. A big mistake. I'm gonna have to ask you not to see Mantan anymore.
answer: Work related or otherwise?

question: Otherwise. I trust you know the difference. You're an intelligent woman, finished at NYU.
answer: DeLa, kiss my big black ass.

question: And that's how you got me in the first place.
answer: I want you to please view this. It may save your Life.

question: You shouldn't even be mad at me over Sloan.
answer: What you did is dead wrong.

question: Oh, is it? Buddy boy, in this business if people don't produce, they get fired.
answer: Sloan is the hardest working person I've ever met.

question: Let me ask you a question, if I may. How do you think she got the job in the first place? I don't mean to burst your bubble, Mantan the Marvelous, but Sloan is an opportunity.
answer: I don't believe it.

question: Do I have to spell it out for you? In fact, go ask Sloan yourself.
answer: How did you get this gig?

question: How did you get this gig?
answer: Worked my black ass off, first as an intern, then worked my way up to this position.

question: You leave something out?
answer: After my internship expired, Dela was impressed and offered me a position as his assistant.

question: And?
answer: And what?

question: Stop playing me Sloan.
answer: Just ask me what you want to know.

question: Oh, you gonna make me say it.
answer: Say what, Manray?

question: Did you ever sleep with DeLa?
answer: We did it one time, only once. It had nothing to do with the job, it was stupid. Everything I've got I've earned.

question: Aw, c'mon.
answer: That's ancient history. That has nothing to do with you and I.

question: So you say. Sloan, you wuz gonna use me up just like you used Dela? Work it to the top. I never imagined people in this biz could flip on you like "IHOP." I'm damn happy DeLa fired ya ass.
answer: Forget about me, are you a puppet for DeLa?

question: Don't try to change to the subject.
answer: Why don't you answer?

question: I know I won't be your puppet.
answer: You can go now.

question: Hello, Mommy, how are you?
answer: I'm doing okay. Been reading about your show, it's all over everywhere. I watched it's all over everywhere. I watched it once. I thought you said there would be no buffoonery.

question: You going to attack me too. The show is a hit. Aren't you happy for me?
answer: Of course I'm happy for you. You've worked very hard for your success.

question: Yes I have, very hard. Has Daddy called?
answer: No.

question: Not at all?
answer: You know how your Daddy is.

question: If and when he calls, please don't forget to ask him if he's seen Mantan.
answer: I won't forget. When are you coming up here to see your mother?

question: Kook and the Gang, it's Manray. Let's do the taping. You go back to your dressing room, get dressed and blacken up.
answer: I'm not playin' myself no mo'.

question: How you sound?
answer: I won't do it anymore.

question: Manray, I'm very sorry about ya boy Cheeba and Sloan. Believe me, it gave me no joy pulling ya coattail about her, just lookin' out for a brother. I feel you, all this stuff happenin' at once but you can't let if affect your work. You gotta be professional.
answer: I'm always gonna be that. But I ain't doing no more buck dancing.

question: No costume. No blackface.
answer: No. No.

question: Whaddup? Whaddup?
answer: You truly are a dancing fool.

question: Don't start none, won't be none.
answer: You is one dead nigger.

question: What did I do?
answer: What did you do? Brothers, he asks what did he do?

question: Get up and put that tape in. Do what I say. Don't make me have to use this.
answer: I didn't think this was in your studies at NYU.

question: Watch this. This is what you contributed to. Because of you, Manray is dead. Mu brother's dead. It's all because of you.
answer: I'm sorry. I didn't know anyone would get hurt. I'm sorry, please give me that gun before you hurt yourself. Give me the gun.

question: I told you but you wouldn't listen. You never listened to me.
answer: Give me the gun. Go, get out of here. Go home.
